Description: Overweight and obesity affect two-thirds of the U.S. population and most Americans are insufficiently active and consume diets that are suboptimal.  These issues are even more prevalent and associated with poorer outcomes in populations at greater risk (e.g., racial and ethnic minorities, rural dwellers, older adults, and cancer survivors). This forum will detail two different approaches – one being a multi-level, community-based intervention aimed at reducing sugar-sweetened beverage consumption as a means of primary prevention and the other being a minimal touch, internet-based approach to improve multiple behaviors among cancer survivors across the U.S.  These approaches will be contextualized within the extant body of lifestyle interventions that are aimed at cancer prevention and control – calling-out the challenges that need to be surmounted in future research and current funding opportunities.
Location: Ballroom 6 B - Upper Level - Convention Center
SearchResultBody: FO06. Lifestyle Choices, the Food Environment, and Health Equity Impact Cancer Prevention and Control - But Are There Solutions? And What Are the Opportunities for Future Research?

Title: Lifestyle Choices, the Food Environment, and Health Equity Impact Cancer Prevention and Control - But Are There Solutions? And What Are the Opportunities for Future Research?
